[MATH_1] spectral theory and heat dynamics of locally symmetric spaces Lizhen Ji Email: lji@umich.edu, Address: 1834 East Hall, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1043, USA. Partially supported by NSF grant DMS 0604878 \\ Department of Mathematics, University of Michigan Andreas Weber Email: andreas.weber@math.uni-karlsruhe.de, Address: Englerstr. 2, 76128 Karlsruhe, Germany. \\ Institut f\"ur Algebra und Geometrie, Universit\"at Karlsruhe (TH)

abstract In this paper we first derive several results concerning the [MATH_2] spectrum of locally symmetric spaces with rank one. In particular, we show that there is an open subset of [MATH_3] consisting of eigenvalues of the [MATH_4] Laplacian if [MATH_5] and that corresponding eigenfunctions are given by certain Eisenstein series. On the other hand, if [MATH_6] there is at most a discrete set of real eigenvalues of the [MATH_7] Laplacian. These results are used in the second part of this paper in order to show that the dynamics of the [MATH_8] heat semigroups for [MATH_9] is very different from the dynamics of the [MATH_10] heat semigroups if [MATH_11] .\\
Keywords: Locally symmetric spaces, [MATH_12] heat semigroups, Eisenstein series, [MATH_13] spectrum, chaotic semigroups. \\[1mm]

The purpose of this paper is twofold. We are first concerned with the [MATH_14] spectrum of the Laplace-Beltrami operator on locally symmetric spaces with rank one and then we will use the obtained results about the [MATH_15] spectrum in order to show that the dynamics of the [MATH_16] heat semigroups for [MATH_17] is very different from the dynamics of the [MATH_18] heat semigroups if [MATH_19] .

In contrast to the [MATH_20] spectrum of the Laplace-Beltrami operator on locally symmetric spaces the [MATH_21] spectrum (as set), [MATH_22] , is only known in special situations. But there are several reasons to study also the [MATH_23] spectrum.\\ Firstly, from a physical point of view, the natural space to study heat diffusion is [MATH_24] : If the function [MATH_25] denotes the heat distribution at the time [MATH_26] , the total amount of heat in some region [MATH_27] is given by the [MATH_28] norm of [MATH_29] and hence, the [MATH_30] norm has a physical meaning. But, on the other hand, [MATH_31] is more difficult to handle than the reflexive [MATH_32] spaces ( [MATH_33] ) as the heat semigroup on [MATH_34] ( [MATH_35] ) is always bounded analytic whereas this is in general not true for the heat semigroup on [MATH_36] .\\ Secondly, there are already many results for differential operators on domains of euclidean space concerning various aspects of [MATH_37] spectral theory, see e.g. MR1269649,MR1103113,MR1345724,MR1458713,MR836002,MR869525,MR1602267,MR1673414,MR1824257,MR1224619,MR1420468 .

Another point to mention is the fact that the question whether the [MATH_38] spectrum of the Laplace-Beltrami operator on a Riemannian manifold depends non-trivially on [MATH_39] is related to the geometry, in particular the volume growth, of the respective manifold MR1250269 . But even if one is only interested in the [MATH_40] case, it could be worth studying the [MATH_41] spectra, as the knowledge of the [MATH_42] spectra yields in some cases further information on the decay of [MATH_43] eigenfunctions of the Laplace-Beltrami operator (see e.g. MR937635,Ji:2007fk,MR1016445 ). Furthermore, in MR1470419 J. Wang was interested in the [MATH_44] spectrum of the Laplacian on complete Riemannian manifolds with non-negative Ricci curvature. In order to calculate this spectrum he first calculated the [MATH_45] spectrum and then used a result of Sturm MR1250269 to show that the [MATH_46] spectrum does not depend on [MATH_47] .

And finally, in the theory of (locally) symmetric spaces there are new phenomena that cannot occur in the [MATH_48] case. One example for this is the fact that the [MATH_49] spectrum ( [MATH_50] ) of a symmetric space of non-compact type contains an uncountable number of eigenvalues of the Laplace-Beltrami operator on [MATH_51] . More precisely, we have the following result by Taylor:

theorem [cf. MR1016445 ] taylor Let [MATH_52] denote a symmetric space of non-compact type. Then for any [MATH_53] we have [MATH_54] where [MATH_55] Furthermore, if [MATH_56] any point in the interior of the parabolic region [MATH_57] is an eigenvalue for [MATH_58] and eigenfunctions corresponding to these eigenvalues are given by spherical functions. theorem

For [MATH_59] we have [MATH_60] and [MATH_61] has no eigenvalues (for a definition of [MATH_62] we refer to Section symmetric spaces ). This follows easily by using the Helgason-Fourier transform which turns [MATH_63] into a multiplication operator.

The [MATH_64] spectrum of certain locally symmetric spaces was examined in various articles: In MR937635 Davies, Simon, and Taylor determined the [MATH_65] spectrum of real hyperbolic spaces and certain geometrically finite quotients [MATH_66] . For symmetric spaces of non-compact type with rank one the results by Lohou\'e and Rychener in MR689073 should be mentioned. They derived estimates of the resolvent [MATH_67] of the Laplacian on [MATH_68] spaces. More precisely, in the rank one case, all the complex numbers [MATH_69] are determined such that the respective resolvent is a bounded operator on [MATH_70] . More general locally symmetric spaces are treated in MR1016445,MR2342629 but a precise identification of the [MATH_71] spectrum (as set) was only obtained if the universal covering is a rank [MATH_72] symmetric space. Related results are also contained in the classical paper MR0367561 by Clerc and Stein. \\

One of the aims in this paper is to derive similar results as in Theorem taylor for locally symmetric spaces [MATH_73] with rank one. For this, we first establish some [MATH_74] estimates of Eisenstein series which are generalized eigenfunctions for the Laplacian and therefore, they can be regarded as analog to the spherical functions on symmetric spaces of non-compact type. Our estimates show that plenty of the Eisenstein series are contained in [MATH_75] if [MATH_76] . From this result in turn, it will follow that these Eisenstein series are actually (honest) eigenfunctions for the [MATH_77] Laplacian, [MATH_78] .

A point to mention here is that, compared to symmetric spaces, the roles [MATH_79] and [MATH_80] are interchanged. This means that the interior of a similarly defined parabolic region [MATH_81] consists (besides a discrete set) of eigenvalues if [MATH_82] . If [MATH_83] there is only a discrete set of real eigenvalues possible.

In the second part of this paper we investigate the dynamics of the [MATH_84] heat semigroups [MATH_85] on locally symmetric spaces [MATH_86] with rank one and on products of rank one spaces. As all these spaces [MATH_87] have finite volume, it follows from H\"older's inequality [MATH_88] if [MATH_89] and hence, the semigroup [MATH_90] can be regarded as an extension of the semigroup [MATH_91] (see Section heat semigroup for further details). In this part, we will make use of the results concerning the [MATH_92] spectrum in order to show that the [MATH_93] heat semigroups on locally symmetric spaces with rank one have a certain chaotic behavior if [MATH_94] . This contrasts the fact that such a behavior is not possible for the [MATH_95] heat semigroups if [MATH_96] . One reason for this is that the spaces [MATH_97] become larger and larger if [MATH_98] and hence, there is more space for potential chaotic behavior available. In particular, if [MATH_99] there are suddenly plenty of Eisenstein series contained in [MATH_100] .

If the ( [MATH_101] -)rank of a locally symmetric space with finite volume is greater than one the theory of Eisenstein series is more complicated than in the case of rank one but similar results hold in this case, too. A first step into this direction is Proposition products where Riemannian products of locally symmetric spaces with rank one are treated. The general case is more difficult to work out but as the asymptotic behavior of an automorphic form at infinity is controlled by its constant term a similar result as Proposition prop main can be proven. We plan to treat the higher [MATH_102] -rank case in a future publication.
Analogous results for symmetric spaces of non-compact type have been obtained in Ji:nr .
The heat semigroup on [MATH_103] spaces heat semigroup

One knows that the [MATH_294] spectrum [MATH_295] of the Laplace-Beltrami operator [MATH_296] on a rank one (non-compact) locally symmetric space [MATH_297] is the union of a point spectrum and an absolutely continuous spectrum. The point spectrum consists of a (possibly infinite) sequence of eigenvalues [MATH_298] with finite multiplicities such that below any finite number there are only finitely many eigenvalues. The absolutely continuous spectrum equals [MATH_299] where [MATH_300] . There are many different definitions of chaos. We will use the following one which is basically an adaption of Devaney's definition MR1046376 to the setting of strongly continuous semigroups, cf. MR1468101 .

definition A strongly continuous semigroup [MATH_543] on a Banach space [MATH_544] is called chaotic if the following two conditions hold: itemize [ (i) ] There exists an [MATH_545] such that its orbit [MATH_546] is dense in [MATH_547] . MR1468101 . [ (4) ] If both subsets [MATH_562] and [MATH_563] are dense in [MATH_564] , the semigroup [MATH_565] has dense orbits. However, this condition is not necessary, cf. MR1468101 . [ (5) ] Chaotic semigroups exist only on infinite dimensional Banach spaces. In the theory of dynamical systems chaotic semigroups are highly unwanted because of their difficult dynamics. Not much more appreciated are so called subspace chaotic semigroups:

definition A strongly continuous semigroup [MATH_601] on a Banach space [MATH_602] is called subspace chaotic if there is a closed, [MATH_603] invariant subspace [MATH_604] of [MATH_605] such that the restriction [MATH_606] is a chaotic semigroup on [MATH_607] . definition
Because of Remark remark1 such a subspace is always infinite dimensional.
